fold.translation[0].definitions[0].defin: to bend a piece of paper, cloth etc by laying or pressing one part over another
fold.translation[0].definitions[0].examp: Fold the paper along the dotted line.
It’ll fit in if you fold it in half.
Spoon the filling onto the dough, fold it over, and press down the edges.
fold.translation[0].definitions[1].defin: to fold something several times so that it makes a small neat shape
fold.translation[0].definitions[1].examp: I wish you kids would fold up your clothes!
fold.translation[0].definitions[2].defin: if something such as a piece of furniture folds, or you fold it, you make it smaller or move it to a different position by bending it
fold.translation[0].definitions[2].examp: The chairs fold flat for storage.
a useful little bed that folds away when you don’t need it
Can you fold the shutters back?
fold.translation[0].definitions[3].defin: if an organization folds, it closes because it does not have enough money to continue
fold.translation[0].definitions[4].defin: to cover something, especially by wrapping it in material or putting your hand over it
fold.translation[0].definitions[4].examp: a silver dagger folded in a piece of white cloth
fold.translation[1].definitions[0].defin: a line made in paper or material when you fold one part of it over another
fold.translation[1].definitions[0].examp: Bend back the card and cut along the fold.
fold.translation[1].definitions[1].defin: the folds in material, skin etc are the loose parts that hang over other parts of it
fold.translation[1].definitions[1].examp: Her dress hung in soft folds.
fold.translation[1].definitions[2].defin: a small area of a field surrounded by a wall or fence where sheep are kept for safety
fold.translation[1].definitions[3].defin: a bend in layers of rock, caused by underground movements in the earth
fold.translation[2].definitions[0].defin: of a particular number of kinds
fold.translation[2].definitions[0].examp: The government’s role in health care is twofold: first, to provide the resources and, second, to make them work better for patients.
fold.translation[2].definitions[1].examp: The value of the house has increased fourfold  (=it is now worth four times as much as before).
fold.translation[3].definitions[0].defin: if a business folds or folds up, it stops operating or trading because it does not have enough money to continue
fold.translation[3].definitions[0].examp: The U.K. engineering firm has folded today with the loss of 30 jobs.
His jewellery importing business folded in less than a year.
As the recession deepened, the company folded up.
fold.translation[4].definitions[0].examp: The value of the house has increased fourfold in the last ten years  (=it is now worth four times as much as it was ten years ago).
